statement:
The sequence $(1 + 1/n)^n$ is increasing.

To see this, rewrite $1 + (1/n) = (1 + n)/n$ and divide two consecutive
terms of the sequence: $$\begin{aligned}
{ \left( 1 + {1 \over n} \right)^n \over  \left( 1 + {1
\over n-1} \right)^{n-1} } &=&
{ \left( {n+1 \over n} \right)^n \over \left( {n \over n-1}
\right)^{n-1} } \\
&=& \left( {(n-1)(n+1) \over n^2} \right)^{n-1} {n+1 \over n} \\
&=& \left( 1 - {1 \over n^2} \right)^{n-1} \left( 1 + {1 \over n}
\right) \\ \end{aligned}$$

Since $(1 - x)^n \ge 1 - nx$, we have $$\begin{aligned}
{ \left( 1 + {1 \over n} \right)^n \over  \left( 1 + {1
\over n-1} \right)^{n-1} } &\ge&
\left( 1 - {n-1 \over n^2} \right) \left( 1 + {1 \over n}
\right) \\
&=& 1 + {1 \over n^3}\\
&>& 1,\end{aligned}$$ hence the sequence is increasing.

The sequence $(1 + 1/n)^{n+1}$ is decreasing.

As before, rewrite $1 + (1/n) = (1 + n)/n$ and divide two consecutive
terms of the sequence: $$\begin{aligned}
{ \left( 1 + {1 \over n} \right)^{n+1} \over  \left( 1 + {1
\over n-1} \right)^{n} } &=&
{ \left( {n+1 \over n} \right)^{n+1} \over \left( {n \over n-1}
\right)^{n} } \\
&=& \left( {(n-1)(n+1) \over n^2} \right)^{n} {n+1 \over n} \\
&=& \left( 1 - {1 \over n^2} \right)^{n} \left( 1 + {1 \over n}
\right) \\ \end{aligned}$$

Writing $1 + 1/n$ as $1 + n/n^2$ and applying the inequality
$1 + n/n^2 \le (1 + 1/n^2)^n$, we obtain $$\begin{aligned}
{ \left( 1 + {1 \over n} \right)^{n+1} \over  \left( 1 + {1
\over n-1} \right)^{n} } &\le&
\left( 1 - {1 \over n^2} \right)^{n} \left( 1 + {1 \over n^2}
\right)^n \\ 
&=& \left( 1 - {1 \over n^4} \right)^{n} \\
&<& 1, \\\end{aligned}$$ hence the sequence is decreasing.

For all positive integers $m$ and $n$, we have
$(1 + 1/m)^{m} < (1 + 1/n)^{n+1}$.

We consider three cases.

Suppose that $m = n$. Since $n > 0$, we have $1/n >0$ and $1 < 1 + 1/n$.
Hence, $(1 + 1/n)^{n} < (1 + 1/n)^{n+1}$.

Suppose that $m < n$. By the previous case,
$(1 + 1/n)^{n} < (1 + 1/n)^{n+1}$. By theorem 1,
$(1 + 1/m)^{m} < (1 + 1/n)^{n}$. Combining,
$(1 + 1/m)^{m} < (1 + 1/n)^{n+1}$.

Suppose that $m > n$. By the first case,
$(1 + 1/m)^{m} <(1 + 1/m)^{m+1}$ By theorem 2,
$(1 + 1/m)^{m+1} < (1 + 1/n)^{n+1}$. Combining,
$(1 + 1/m)^{m} < (1 + 1/n)^{n+1}$.
